explanation:
For a MISRA recursion check we must follow every call path out of cleanup_connection to see whether any path can eventually reach cleanup_connection again. The next analyzer therefore needs the implementations (or stubs) of the following symbols so it can determine whether they (or anything they call) invoke cleanup_connection:

- MHD_destroy_response: Called directly by cleanup_connection; must be inspected to ensure it does not call (directly or indirectly) cleanup_connection.
- MHD_DLOG: Called conditionally inside cleanup_connection; its body may call other functions that could lead back to cleanup_connection.
- __builtin_unreachable: Appears as a callee in the supplied static graph; include to confirm it has no side-effect or indirect calls.
- MHD_itc_activate_: Called by cleanup_connection when signaling the main thread; must be checked for any path that could call cleanup_connection.
- MHD_ITC_IS_VALID_: Guard used before calling MHD_itc_activate_; include because its evaluation might expand to function calls/macros that could participate in a call cycle.
- DLL_remove: Called to remove the connection from lists; include in case list-manipulation routines invoke callbacks that could re-enter cleanup_connection.
- XDLL_remove: Same reason as DLL_remove (alternate list removal used for timeouts).
- DLL_insert: Called to move the connection to the cleanup list; include to ensure insertion routines do not call back into cleanup logic.
- MHD_mutex_lock_chk_: Lock wrapper used around list operations; include because wrappers could call hook/cleanup code.
- MHD_mutex_unlock_chk_: Unlock wrapper corresponding to the lock; include for completeness in lock/unlock wrappers that might call other functions.

Including these symbols lets the next agent construct the transitive call graph starting at cleanup_connection and conclusively determine whether any call sequence leads back to cleanup_connection (i.e., whether direct or indirect recursion exists).
